abstract:
This method is used to estimate the percentage of non-woody riparian coverage along a riverbank. The estimation is based on five transects located on both the right and left banks within a 10m x 10m plot, starting at bankfull level. The estimates are made for the groundstory, understory, and canopy cover of non-woody vegetation.

The CHaMP (Continuous High Resolution AquaticMapping Project) Riparian Structure Method is employed to carry out this calculation. It's important to note that this method follows the guidelines set by Peck et al. (2001), as used in the Environmental Monitoring and Assessment Program (EMAP).

The necessity of this method lies in the importance of riparian vegetation in maintaining a healthy aquatic ecosystem. By estimating the percentage of non-woody cover, we gain valuable insight into the structure and composition of the riparian vegetation. This information can be used to assess the overall health of the riverbank and identify areas where intervention or restoration may be necessary.

The method ensures consistency and accuracy by following well-established techniques for measuring non-woody cover, as outlined in the CHaMP and Peck et al. (2001) methods. This helps to address any potential issues that might arise from inconsistent or unreliable data collection methods. By providing a clear framework for collecting and analyzing data, this method promotes transparency, comparability, and robustness in riparian assessment efforts.
description:
This text discusses the process of estimating the percentage of non-woody riparian coverage using the CHaMP (Collaborative Harvested Modeling Project) - Riparian Structure Method. The measurement is taken at five transects, specifically located on both banks within a 10m x 10m plot, starting from bankfull level.

The method involves assessing the percent of non-woody cover for three distinct layers: groundstory, understory, and canopy. Each layer's coverage is calculated separately at every transect. The CHaMP methodology provides background information on these measurements, which align with the Peck et al. (2001) techniques utilized by the EMAP (Environmental Monitoring and Assessment Program).

In a more detailed description:

The CHaMP Riparian Structure Method is employed to determine the percentage of non-woody riparian coverage within specified plots, located at the bankfull level on both banks. Five individual transects (1, 6, 11, 16, and 21) are assessed for each plot.

The estimation process includes determining the percent of non-woody cover for three distinct layers: groundstory, understory, and canopy. Each layer's coverage is calculated independently for all five transects. The CHaMP methodology, which follows the Peck et al. (2001) techniques used by the EMAP, outlines this procedure in detail.

The groundstory non-woody cover refers to vegetation present below the canopy layer but above the forest floor or ground surface. The understory non-woody cover represents vegetation that grows beneath the canopy and intermingles with the overlying woody vegetation. Lastly, the canopy non-woody cover consists of vegetation growing above the tallest woody vegetation.

Overall, the CHaMP Riparian Structure Method provides a standardized approach for assessing the percentage of non-woody riparian coverage at multiple transects within a specified plot area, following established methods used by the EMAP.
